Knowledge Point: Third, some TAME categories are not allowed in relative clauses, including Modal categories such as Irrealis (§\ref{sec:irrealis}) and Imperative (§\ref{sec:imperative}) and Evidential categories such as Inferential (§\ref{sec:ifr}), Sensory (§\ref{sec:sensory}) and Egophoric Present (§\ref{sec:egophoric}). Knowledge Point: Third, finite relative clauses cannot relativize subjects, and therefore `plain' intransitive verbs (excluding semi-transitive verbs §\ref{sec:semi.transitive} and verbs with goals §\ref{sec:intr.goal}) cannot occur in finite relative clauses (except in the case of locative and time adjunct relativization, §\ref{sec:time.relativization}). Therefore, clauses such as \forme{mɯ-pjɤ-pe} `it was not good' in (\ref{ex:mWpjApe.nW.kotso}) and \forme{tu-ɣɤwu} `it cries/howls' in (\ref{ex:tuGAwu.nW.WmtshAm}) cannot be interpreted as subject relatives `(the thing) that was not good' or `(the wolf) that howls'.

Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:yazi.tAkAmWrkW}), we find a series of non-finite verb forms in \forme{kɯ-} and \forme{kɤ-} in clauses that are object of the com\-ple\-ment-taking verb \japhug{fɕɤt}{tell} (§\ref{sec:velar.infinitives.complement.clauses}). Given the meaning of this example, it could appear to be preferrable to analyze these examples as complement clauses, translating \forme{<yazi> tɤ-kɤ-mɯrkɯ, tɤ-kɤ-ndza} as `(he told him) that he had stolen and eaten a duck' and \forme{ɯ-βri ...nɯ-kɯ-ɬoʁ} as `that his body started itching, and that feathers started growing on it'.
Content 1: \gll tɕe nɯra [pɯ\redp{}pɯ-kɯ-fse] nɯra, [<\textbf{yazi}> tɤ-kɤ-mɯrkɯ, tɤ-kɤ-ndza], qʰe ɕɤr tɕe [\textbf{ɯ-βri} tɤ-kɯ-rɤʑa] qʰe, [ɯ-βri tɕe iɕqʰa, <yazi> ɣɯ \textbf{ɯ-muj} nɯ-kɯ-ɬoʁ], nɯra pjɤ-fɕɤt. | \gls LNK DEM:PL TOTAL\redp{}PST.IPFV-SBJ:PCP-be.like DEM:PL duck AOR-OBJ:PCP-steal AOR-OBJ:PCP-eat LNK evening LOC 3SG.POSS-body AOR-SBJ:PCP-itch LNK 3SG.POSS-body LOC the.aforementioned duck GEN 3SG.POSS-feather AOR-SBJ:PCP-come.out DEM:PL IFR-tell | \glt `He told [the old man] everything that had happened, about \textbf{the duck that he had stolen and eaten}, and \textbf{his body itching, and the duck feathers that had grown on it}.'

Knowledge Point: However, the problem with analyzing these clauses as infinitival complement clauses is that the intransitive motion verb \japhug{ɬoʁ}{come out}, being dynamic, never takes a \forme{kɤ-} infinitive, and that the form \forme{nɯ-kɯ-ɬoʁ} can only be a subject participle `(something) that has come out'. Subsection: Participial clauses in core argument function \label{sec:relative.pretence
Knowledge Point: Some verbs such as the verbs of pretence \japhug{ʑɣɤpa}{pretend} and \japhug{nɯɕpɯz}{pretend} `dress up as', `imitate' select subject participle clauses as objects or semi-objects such as \forme{kɯ-ngo} in (\ref{ex:kWngo.toZGApa}), which could appear to be similar to the purposive complement of motion verbs (§\ref{sec:purposive.clause.motion.verbs}).
Content 1: \gll [kɯ-ngo] to-ʑɣɤpa tɕe | \gls SBJ:PCP-be.sick IFR-pretend LNK | \glt `She pretended to be sick.'

Subsection: Participial clauses in core argument function \label{sec:relative.pretence
Knowledge Point: However, there is clear evidence that these clauses are in fact headless relatives: (\ref{ex:kWngo.toZGApa}) can literally be translated as `she pretended to be a sick person'. The difference with purposive clauses can be shown by three tests.
Content 1: \gll [kɯ-ngo] to-ʑɣɤpa tɕe | \gls SBJ:PCP-be.sick IFR-pretend LNK | \glt `She pretended to be sick.'

Knowledge Point: First, unlike motion verbs, pretence verbs can take nouns as objects (as shown by \ref{ex:qaɕpa.tonWCpWz} and \ref{ex:tAkWnWCpWz.pjAsWXsAl}) instead of clauses with subject participles.

Knowledge Point: Third, we find examples like (\ref{ex:Wmi.kWmNAm.tonWCpWznW}) where the subject of the verb in the main clause is not coreferent with the subject of the participial clause but with the possessor of the subject. Content 1: \gll tɕeri [sŋaʁspa kɯ tɯ\redp{}ta-tɯt] nɯ to-stu | \gls LNK sorcerer ERG TOTAL\redp{}AOR:3\flobv{}-say[II] DEM IFR-do.like | \glt `He did it everything the way that the sorcerer had said.'

Content 2: \gll [[``\textbf{nɯ} \textbf{a-tɤ-fse} \textbf{ɲɯ-ra}"] tɤ-tɯ-tɯt] nɯ tɤ-stu-t-a ŋu | \gls DEM IRR-PFV-be.like SENS-be.needed AOR-2-say[II] DEM AOR-do.like-PST:TR-1SG be:FACT | \glt `I did it [the way that] you said should be done.'
Content 3: \gll tɕeri [sŋaʁspa kɯ tɯ\redp{}ta-tɯt] nɯ to-stu | \gls LNK sorcerer ERG TOTAL\redp{}AOR:3\flobv{}-say[II] DEM IFR-do.like | \glt `He did it everything the way that the sorcerer had said.'

Knowledge Point: What is remarkable about the construction in (\ref{ex:YWra.tAtWtWt.nW}) is that the relativized element is not a noun, but the (object) complement clause \forme{nɯ a-tɤ-fse ɲɯ-ra} `it should be (done) like that', embedded within the relative.
Content 1: \gll [[``\textbf{nɯ} \textbf{a-tɤ-fse} \textbf{ɲɯ-ra}"] tɤ-tɯ-tɯt] nɯ tɤ-stu-t-a ŋu | \gls DEM IRR-PFV-be.like SENS-be.needed AOR-2-say[II] DEM AOR-do.like-PST:TR-1SG be:FACT | \glt `I did it [the way that] you said should be done.'
